customer_name: East Coast Exotic Animal Rescue Inc
site_name: East Coast Exotic Animal Rescue Inc

citations.narrative:
During a review of records, it was observed that the facility only accounts for 44 fallow deer on their inventory records but
there are 67 fallow deer at the facility. Facility representatives stated that fallow deer born this year had not yet been
added to the records.
Exhibitors need to make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose animals owned, held, or otherwise
in their possession and these records need to include any offspring born. Failure to do so can inhibit animal tracking
efforts.
Correct by ensuring that records include correct counts of animals and include all births.

A large tree has fallen onto the perimeter fence, behind the vervet enclosure, which has caused the fencing to collapse to
the ground. The facility has removed some of the branches, but the majority of the tree trunk remains on the fencing.
Areas of the perimeter fence which are in a state of disrepair impact the integrity of the fence and can potentially allow the
entry of other animals.
Perimeter fences must be constructed so that they prevent entry of unauthorized persons or other unwanted species.
Correct by removing the tree from the perimeter fence.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There are tall weeds surrounding the outside housing area for the three brown capuchins. The weeds are approximately
two feet in height and surround a majority of the enclosure.
Uncontrolled weeds can make it difficult to facilitate cleaning of the premises and can allow for harborage of pests.
The weeds must be cut in order to maintain proper husbandry practices and pest control.

During the inspection, a Patagonian cavy was observed with two wounds on the left side of its neck. When asked about
the animal, the facility representative stated that it had wounded its neck on the fencing material in its previous enclosure
on Saturday. After the incident, both cavies were moved to a different enclosure, and the Attending veterinarian was
consulted for further instructions regarding the care of the animal.
In the fallow deer enclosure, there are several areas in a state of disrepair. The temporary fence in the front of the
enclosure, has partially fallen causing sharp points to be exposed to the animals. In the same area, there is a gap in the
bottom corner of the temporary fencing approximately 1 foot high by 1 foot wide where an animal could become
entrapped. Adjacent to this area, there is a pile of metal fencing on the ground with sharp points exposed and the
potential for entanglement. On the small building in the same enclosure, there are multiple wooden boards which are
detaching from the structure.
Enclosures with gaps, sharp edges, or unstable structures can allow for the entrapment, serious injury, escape, or death
of the animals.
The facility must remove, repair, or replace the above mentioned items in the fallow deer enclosure to protect the animals
from injury and contain them.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
An accumulation of rodent feces was found on the storage shelves and unused food bowls in the facility's indoor bird
area. The facility stated that they have attempted several pest management techniques, however, their current program
does not appear to be effective in eliminating the pests.
Failure to maintain an effective program to control mammalian pests can have a negative impact on the the health of the
birds through the spread of disease by contamination of animal areas and feed.
The licensee must correct by implementing an effective pest control program in all animal areas.
Correct by: 09/07/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
During a review of records, it was observed that the facility only accounts for 44 fallow deer on their inventory records but 
there are 67 fallow deer at the facility. Facility representatives stated that fallow deer born this year had not yet been 
added to the records.  
Exhibitors need to make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose animals owned, held, or otherwise 
in their possession and these records need to include any offspring born. Failure to do so can inhibit animal tracking 
efforts. 
Correct by ensuring that records include correct counts of animals and include all births. 
3.78(d)  Repeat
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
A large tree has fallen onto the perimeter fence, behind the vervet enclosure, which has caused the fencing to collapse to 
the ground. The facility has removed some of the branches, but the majority of the tree trunk remains on the fencing.  
Areas of the perimeter fence which are in a state of disrepair impact the integrity of the fence and can potentially allow the 
entry of other animals. 
Perimeter fences must be constructed so that they prevent entry of unauthorized persons or other unwanted species. 
Correct by removing the tree from the perimeter fence. 
3.84(c)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There are tall weeds surrounding the outside housing area for the three brown capuchins. The weeds are approximately 
two feet in height and surround a majority of the enclosure. 
Uncontrolled weeds can make it difficult to facilitate cleaning of the premises and can allow for harborage of pests. 
The weeds must be cut in order to maintain proper husbandry practices and pest control. 
3.125(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general.

During the inspection, a Patagonian cavy was observed with two wounds on the left side of its neck. When asked about 
the animal, the facility representative stated that it had wounded its neck on the fencing material in its previous enclosure 
on Saturday. After the incident, both cavies were moved to a different enclosure, and the Attending veterinarian was 
consulted for further instructions regarding the care of the animal.  
In the fallow deer enclosure, there are several areas in a state of disrepair. The temporary fence in the front of the 
enclosure, has partially fallen causing sharp points to be exposed to the animals. In the same area, there is a gap in the 
bottom corner of the temporary fencing approximately 1 foot high by 1 foot wide where an animal could become 
entrapped. Adjacent to this area, there is a pile of metal fencing on the ground with sharp points exposed and the 
potential for entanglement. On the small building in the same enclosure, there are multiple wooden boards which are 
detaching from the structure.  
Enclosures with gaps, sharp edges, or unstable structures can allow for the entrapment, serious injury, escape, or death 
of the animals. 
The facility must remove, repair, or replace the above mentioned items in the fallow deer enclosure to protect the animals 
from injury and contain them. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
An accumulation of rodent feces was found on the storage shelves and unused food bowls in the facility's indoor bird 
area. The facility stated that they have attempted several pest management techniques, however, their current program 
does not appear to be effective in eliminating the pests. 
Failure to maintain an effective program to control mammalian pests can have a negative impact on the the health of the 
birds through the spread of disease by contamination of animal areas and feed.  
The licensee must correct by implementing an effective pest control program in all animal areas. 
Correct by: 09/07/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
